The XANES and EXAFS experiments were conducted at the HAXMA beamline of the Canadian Light Source (CLS), and the in-situ PDF measurements were carried out at the BXDS-HEW beamline at CLS, which receives support from the Canada Foundation for Innovation (CFI), NSERC, the University of Saskatchewan, the Government of Saskatchewan, Western Economic Diversification Canada, the National Research Council (NRC), and the Canadian Institutes of Health Research. Special thanks are extended to Dr. Graham King at the BXDS-HEW beamline of the Canadian Light Source for his assistance with the in-situ PDF experiment. Furthermore, the HAADF-TEM analysis was performed at the 4D LABS core facility at Simon Fraser University (SFU), with financial support from the Canada Foundation for Innovation (CFI), the British Probing the effects of metal loading and calcination temperature on AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalyst in ozonative epoxidation of ethylene Nazanin Charchi Aghdam Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization a Ning Chen Writing – review & editing Supervision Software Methodology Formal analysis a b Beatriz Diaz Moreno Writing – review & editing Software Formal analysis b Jafar Soltan Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Saskatchewan, 57 Campus Drive, Saskatoon, SK S7N 5A9, Canada Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Saskatchewan 57 Campus Drive Saskatoon SK S7N 5A9 Canada Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Saskatchewan, 57 Campus Drive, Saskatoon, SK, S7N 5A9, Canada b Canadian Light Source Inc., University of Saskatchewan, 101 Perimeter Road, Saskatoon, SK S7N 0×4, Canada Canadian Light Source Inc., University of Saskatchewan 101 Perimeter Road Saskatoon SK S7N 0×4 Canada Canadian Light Source Inc., University of Saskatchewan, 101 Perimeter Road, Saskatoon, SK, S7N 0×4, Canada ⁎ Corresponding author. This work explores the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene to produce ethylene oxide over AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalysts which is a novel reaction pathway that remains underexplored due to its recent emergence. The study focuses on the effects of silver loading and calcination temperature. Higher silver loading was found to increase the abundance of silver species on the support surface, which accelerates ozone decomposition and elevates surface oxygen coverage. This enhanced oxygen coverage, along with reduced ethylene adsorption, promotes the direct formation of ethylene oxide while maintaining high conversion rates. The catalyst with 10 wt% silver achieved an ethylene conversion of 96 % and an ethylene oxide selectivity of 68 %. Increasing the calcination temperature from 350 ºC to 750 ºC altered silver oxidation states and improved catalyst stability and ozone conversion. However, no significant enhancement in ethylene oxide selectivity was observed, likely due to limited improvement in surface oxygen coverage under those conditions. which are considered beneficial for epoxidation. Structural evolution of silver species under different atmospheres was investigated using in situ pair distribution function (PDF) analysis, revealing successive redox transformations during heating. Overall, Ag loading had a more significant impact on ethylene oxide selectivity than calcination temperature, highlighting it as a key factor in optimizing catalyst performance in ozonative epoxidation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ozonative epoxidation Ethylene oxide Silver catalysts In-situ pair distribution function Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic ozonative epoxidation of ethylene to produce ethylene oxide at ambient temperature presents a promising opportunity for advancing chemical reactions toward more selective and energy-efficient processes with a lower carbon footprint. In this process, ozone is utilized to generate electrophilic oxygen, which facilitates its insertion into the ethylene double bond and promotes epoxide formation. This approach significantly enhances the selective oxygen coverage on the catalyst surface, enabling high ethylene oxide (EO) selectivity while maintaining substantial ethylene conversion [1]. However, as a newly developed process, further research is necessary to investigate key catalyst parameters and optimize its performance. Ag is the only metal known to selectively catalyze ethylene epoxidation. Supported Ag catalysts, typically on α-Al₂O₃, are widely used, with loadings from 7–20 wt% [2–5]. Low-surface-area α-Al₂O₃ minimizes hydroxyl groups, improving EO selectivity by reducing overoxidation [5]. While unpromoted Ag achieves 40–50 % EO selectivity, promoters such as Cs, Re, or Mo, and trace chlorine in the feed, can increase selectivity up to 90 % [3,6,7]. In catalytic reactions, factors such as metal loading and calcination temperature significantly affect catalyst performance by affecting structural, electronic, and chemical properties [8–14]. These factors are crucial in influencing the coordination environment of the catalyst, as well as its selectivity and EO yield. In parallel, calcination temperature has a profound effect on the physical and chemical properties of silver (Ag)-based catalysts. The temperature at which the catalyst is calcined influences key factors such as particle size, oxidation state, and surface characteristics [15–18]. These properties, in turn, dictate the catalyst’s ability to decompose ozone [8–13] and facilitate the selective epoxidation of ethylene [1]. This study investigates the effects of metal loading and calcination temperature on AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalysts for the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene. Due to its exceptional electronic properties, Ag exhibits high catalytic activity for both ozone decomposition and the selective epoxidation of ethylene [1]. In this study, high-surface-area γ-Al₂O₃ was employed to enhance ozone decomposition, and the catalyst was intentionally kept unpromoted to maintain a simple structure, allowing a focused investigation of the effects of Ag loading and calcination temperature on performance. To study the effect of metal loading, AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalysts with silver loadings ranging from 1 % to 10 % wt% were synthesized and calcined at 350°C. To examine the effect of calcination temperature, catalysts with Ag loadings of 2.5 % and 5 % wt% were synthesized and calcined at different temperatures, ranging from 250 °C to 750 °C for 2.5 wt% Ag and from 350 °C to 750 °C for 5 wt% Ag. Various analyses, including Ag K edge X-ray Absorption Near Edge Structure (XANES) and Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF-TEM), were conducted to investigate the changes in the electronic and structural properties of the catalyst. Additionally, in-situ Pair Distribution Function (PDF) analysis was performed to study the effects of calcination temperature on the catalyst structure, and the results were compared with the EXAFS data. This approach allows for a comprehensive understanding of how metal loading and calcination temperature influence the performance of catalyst in the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were purchased from Alfa Aesar and used as received. Supported AgOx catalysts were synthesized via dry impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (pore volume: 0.60 cm³/g, surface area: 219 m²/g) using silver nitrate (99.995 %) as the precursor material. To study the effect of metal loading, catalysts with Ag loadings ranging from 1 % to 10 % were calcined at 350°C. For investigating the effect of calcination temperature, catalysts with Ag loadings of 2.5 % and 5 % were prepared. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried at 80°C for 10 h, followed by calcination at temperatures between 250°C and 750°C for 2 h. Prepared catalysts were denoted as Ag-X/Al2O3-Y where X represents the Ag loading in wt% and Y indicates the calcination temperature in °C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis were performed using an FEI Tecnai Osiris microscope at 4D LABS, Simon Fraser University. Samples were prepared by sonicating in isopropyl alcohol and placing them on a carbon grid. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements, including XANES and EXAFS, were conducted at the HXMA beamline of the Canadian Light Source (CLS) to analyze the Ag K-edge spectra. Ag K-edge experiments used a Si (220) monochromator, and energy calibration was based on an Ag foil. The samples were prepared by mixing with boron nitride, secured with Kapton tape, and measured in fluorescence mode using a 32 element Ge detector. Standard procedures for data processing, including energy calibration, normalization, and background removal, were performed using ATHENA software [19]. EXAFS data were fitted using WinXAS software, with theoretical phases generated by FEFF7 [20]. In-situ total scattering high energy Pair Distribution Function (PDF) experiments were conducted during the calcination of AgOx/Al2O3 catalyst with Ag loading of 5 wt% under air and nitrogen flow. For in situ analysis, the Ag catalyst was impregnated onto the Al₂O₃ support and dried overnight at 80°C. The dried sample was then carefully filled into capillary tubes with diameters of 1 mm for experiments under air flow and 0.8 mm for those under nitrogen flow before being integrated into the experimental setup at the BXDS-WHE (Brockhouse Diffraction Sector-High Energy Wiggler) beamline of the Canadian Light Source (Fig. S. 1). The temperature was monitored by a thermocouple inserted into the capillary. Data extraction was performed using GSAS-II software [21]. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted with a Kratos AXIS Supra system, calibrated to C 1 s at 284.8 eV, and high-resolution spectra were analyzed with CasaXPS software [22]. 2.3 Catalyst activity measurements The details of the experimental setup and reactor configuration are described in our previous publication [1]. Briefly, catalyst activity measurements were conducted in a packed bed reactor comprising a horizontal Pyrex tube (1/2 in. i.d.) maintained at 25°C and atmospheric pressure, using 0.2 g of catalyst at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 300 lh⁻¹g⁻¹ . Ozone was generated by passing ultra-high-purity oxygen (99.993 %) through an ozone generator (AZCO Industries LTD, HTU-500S) and subsequently mixed with ethylene/nitrogen and nitrogen to achieve inlet flow rates of 0.12 sccm ethylene and 1.2 sccm ozone, corresponding to an ozone/ethylene ratio of 10. A Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer was used for gas phase analysis, incorporating a PIKE long-path gas cell with a 0.1 L volume, a 2.4 m optical length, and KBr windows. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Effect of metal loading Fig. 1 presents the normalized Ag K-edge XANES spectra and enlarged white line position for Ag-X/Al2O3-350 catalysts and reference materials. The white line, which refers to the intense peak just above the absorption edge in XANES spectra and is associated with electronic transitions from core-level electrons (1 s) to unoccupied states (mainly 4d orbitals for silver), provides insight into the oxidation state and local electronic structure of the absorbing atom [23]. As can be seen, the white line position for all AgOx/Al2O3 catalysts was situated between that of AgNO3 and Ag foil, indicating that silver exists as a mixture of Ag⁰ and Ag⁺ species, with Ag⁺ being dominant, as the spectra of all samples closely resemble that of the AgNO₃ standard. At Ag loading of 10 wt%, the white line position shifts slightly toward that of metallic silver, suggesting an increased fraction of Ag⁰. linear combination fitting (LCF) was carried out using normalized μ(E) spectra within a narrow energy window (−20 to +20 eV) around the Ag K-edge jump o minimize the influence of particle size on the spectral features. The fitting results ( Table 1) indicate that for the catalyst with 1 wt% Ag, 85 % of the silver is present as Ag⁺ (comparable to AgNO₃), while 15 % exists as metallic Ag. As the Ag loading increases to 10 wt%, the Ag⁺ fraction declines to 75 %, and the metallic component rises to 25 %. This trend suggests a progressive reduction in silver species as the silver content on the alumina support increases. Fig. 2.a shows the Fourier-transformed (FT) Ag K-edge EXAFS of Ag-X/Al2O3-350 catalysts with various metal loading levels, Ag foil, and Ag2O in R-space (without phase shift correction). The peaks at around 1.5 Å assigns to Ag-O contributions, whereas the peak at around 2.2 Å corresponds to the Ag-Ag contribution. For AgOx/Al2O3 catalysts with low Ag content, the peak due to Ag-O (around 1.7 Å) is predominant, suggesting that Ag species are mainly in the oxidized state. However, by increasing metal loading, contribution and amplitude of the Ag-Ag path become more significant which is consistent with previous XANES results. To determine the local environment of the Ag species in Ag/Al2O3 catalysts, EXAFS curve fitting was performed. Fig. 2.b-f illustrates a comparison between the experimental data and the fitted paths for the magnitude of the total FT, as well as for each Ag-O and Ag-Ag scattering path. Comparison between the experimental data and the fitted paths for both the magnitude and imaginary part of the total FT is shown on Fig. S.2. The fitting parameters, including the coordination number (CN), nearest neighbor distance (R), and Debye-Waller factor (σ2), are presented in Table 1. For all the catalysts, Ag-O and Ag-Ag bonds were found at the interatomic distance ranges of 2.22–2.25 Å and 2.73–2.82 Å respectively, which is in a good agreement with the previous studies for alumina supported silver oxides [24,25]. For Ag-1/Al2O3-350, Ag-O and Ag-Ag bonds were found at the distances of 2.25 Å and 2.73 Å, respectively. Increasing silver loading to 2.5, 3.5, and 5 % gradually changed the local environment of silver. Ag-O bond distances decreased from 2.25 Å in Ag1 % to 2.20 Å in Ag-5/Al2O3-350, while Ag-Ag bond distance increased from 2.73 Å in Ag1 % to 2.81 Å in Ag 5 %. Further increasing Ag loading to 10 %, significantly enhanced Ag-Ag amplitude, increased the coordination number of Ag to 1.2, and led to an increase in the Ag-Ag bond distance to 2.82 Å. (Table 1). These results suggest that when Ag species are introduced onto Al₂O₃, they initially attach through oxygen bridges on the surface. As Ag loading increases, the oxygen bridges become occupied, limiting availability and causing Ag species to interact directly with each other. STEM-HAADF images of the Ag-X/Al₂O₃-350 catalysts ( Fig. 3) revealed morphological changes in Ag dispersion with varying metal loadings (EDX elemental maps are shown in Figs. S3–S7). The corresponding mean Ag particle sizes for each loading, determined from TEM analysis, are summarized in Table 2. As Ag loading increased, an increase in the average particle size of Ag was observed, shifting from 2.4 nm in sample with Ag loading of 1 wt% to 3.6 nm in the one with 10 wt% of Ag. This trend was supported by EXFAS fitting results in which the coordination number for Ag-Ag increased from 0.5 in the catalyst with 1 wt% Ag loading to 1.2 in the catalyst with 10 wt% Ag loading (Table 1) indicating the enlargement in particle size, correlated with a higher coordination number for Ag-Ag in samples with greater Ag loading. However, the relationship between Ag loading and average particle size appears to be more complex, with no discernible general pattern emerging. At 3.5 % Ag loading, there is a reduction in particle size to 2 nm, accompanied by the emergence of small highly dispersed Ag clusters/particles. A similar trend is observed for Ag 5 % calcined at the temperature of 550 °C where newly formed Ag particles are oxidized, leading to the formation of smaller, well-dispersed Ag species which will be discussed in Section 3.1.2. After this stage, Ag particles grow larger, and at 5 wt% loading, they appear more uniform in shape and size. In contrast, the sample with 10 % Ag loading demonstrates less homogeneity, as evident in both TEM images and the standard deviation obtained for the sample. These findings suggest that the nucleation and growth processes for Ag species are complex and influenced by factors beyond just the Ag loading. Initially, when Ag species are loaded onto the Al2O3 support, they anchor on oxide surfaces through oxygen bridges at the particle-support interface. As more Ag species are loaded, the available oxygen bridges on the Al2O3 surface may become depleted. This happens because the oxygen sites become occupied by the growing population of Ag. As a result, the Ag species start to aggregate, forming larger clusters making them more susceptible to oxidation. Oxidation occurs when oxygen from the surrounding environment reacts with Ag on the surface of the particles. This process can lead to the formation of Ag2O on the surface of the larger particles. Under certain conditions, such as high temperatures or exposure to oxygen-rich environments, Ag2O can further decompose. This decomposition results in the formation of smaller metallic Ag particles. The unique oxidation and reduction behavior of Ag can be attributed to its electron configuration, [Kr] 4d¹ ⁰ 5 s ¹ . The single, relatively weakly bounded valence electron in the 5 s orbital enhances the tendency of Ag to undergo both oxidation and reduction. In contrast, the filled 4d orbitals provide stability, making Ag less likely to form bonds with other atoms compared to transition metals with partially filled d orbitals. This combination of a single valence electron and stable inner orbitals contributes to the complex chemistry of Ag [26,27]. One crucial factor in evaluating the performance of AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalysts is the dispersion of Ag particles on the Al₂O₃ support, which describes how well the particles are spread on the surface of the material. Two methods based on TEM and XPS were employed to estimate dispersion. Table 2 presents the dispersion values calculated from TEM analysis, showing an inverse correlation between Ag particle size and dispersion, with larger particles leading to lower dispersion. The highest dispersion of 59 % was observed in the catalyst with 3.5 % Ag loading, indicating well-distributed Ag particles. XPS analysis was also used to assess dispersion by comparing the intensities of Al 2p and Ag 3d for the Ag-X/Al2O3-350 catalysts (Fig S.8 and S.9). XPS is surface-sensitive and detects a high IAg/IAl ratio for small, well-dispersed particles, while poorly dispersed particles show a lower ratio [28,29]. As Ag loading increased, the intensity of the Ag 3d peak grew, resulting in a higher IAg/IAl ratio. This ratio increased from 0.14 for the 1 wt% Ag catalyst to 1.56 for the 10 wt% Ag catalyst, indicating improved Ag dispersion with higher Ag loading. Although TEM and XPS appear to give different trends, this discrepancy reflects the distinct nature of the techniques. TEM measures particle size and derives an average dispersion, which may overlook small clusters and is sensitive to particle size distribution and shape assumptions. In contrast, XPS probes only the near-surface region and is highly responsive to small clusters, which contribute disproportionately to the IAg/IAl ratio. Thus, TEM emphasizes particle growth while XPS highlights surface enrichment, and together they suggest that higher Ag loading results in both larger crystallites and small clusters. Further methodological details are provided in the Supplementary Information (Section S.2). In summary, the combined results from XANES, EXAFS, STEM-HAADF, TEM, and XPS analyses provide a comprehensive understanding of the structural and morphological evolution of Ag species on Al₂O₃ as a function of metal loading. At lower loadings, silver predominantly exists in oxidized form (Ag⁺), well-dispersed via surface oxygen bridges, and forming smaller particles. As loading increases, a greater fraction of metallic silver emerges, accompanied by larger Ag-Ag coordination numbers, greater particle sizes, and partial aggregation. Interestingly, a non-linear relationship between Ag loading and particle size/dispersion suggests the involvement of complex nucleation, growth, and redox dynamics influenced by both surface chemistry and thermal treatment. 3.1.2 Effect of calcination temperature This section discusses how calcination temperature influences Ag/Al₂O₃ catalysts, mainly focusing on catalyst with 5 wt% silver (Ag-5/Al₂O₃-Y). Detailed characterization results are presented to understand how thermal treatment influences silver dispersion, oxidation state, and morphology. To support and extend these findings, additional characterization of Ag-2.5/Al₂O₃-Y was conducted to assess the impact of lower Ag loading under similar calcination conditions. Fig. 4 shows HAADF-STEM images, revealing a reduction in Ag nanoparticle size as the calcination temperature increased (corresponding EDX mapping results are provided in Fig. S.6, Fig. S.10, and Fig. S.11). The Ag nanoparticles exhibited a decrease in size with increasing calcination temperature, indicating that the transformation of Ag species involves complex sequential reactions beyond simple reduction and sintering processes. At 750 °C (Fig. S.12, showing a closer view at 20 nm), smaller Ag particles were observed along with a higher density of highly dispersed Ag species. Fig. 5 presents the XANES spectra, showing a strong resemblance to AgNO₃, indicating Ag¹ ⁺ as the dominant phase. The catalyst calcined at 350°C has a white line position closest to AgNO₃, implying a higher Ag¹ ⁺ content. At 550°C, the white line shifts slightly toward Ag foil, but at 750°C, it reverts closer to AgNO₃ with increased intensity, suggesting electron-deficient Ag species [16]. LCF analysis (Table 4) shows metallic Ag increased from 20 % at 350°C to 28 % at 550°C but decreased to 24 % at 750°C. Fig. 6 compares the experimental data with the fitted paths for the magnitude of the total FT and Ag-O and Ag-Ag scattering paths. The FT-EXAFS Ag K-edge of Ag-5/Al₂O₃-Y catalysts, Ag foil, and Ag₂O in R-space and k-space (without phase shift correction), along with a comparison of the magnitude and imaginary part of the total FT, is shown in Fig. S.13 and Fig. S.14. The Ag-5/Al₂O₃-350 catalyst exhibited a significant Ag−O contribution, indicating the dominance of Ag¹ ⁺ species, as discussed in Section 3.1.1. For Ag-5/Al₂O₃-550 and Ag-5/Al₂O₃-750, more than one FT peak was resolved in the Ag−O bonding R region, suggesting that a single Ag−O path was insufficient. Consequently, an additional Ag−O path was incorporated to better describe the local environment. As the calcination temperature increased to 550 °C, the spectra shifted, resembling Ag foil with a notable Ag−Ag contribution, suggesting partial reduction of Ag species and the formation of metallic Ag. However, the Ag−Ag peak intensity remained lower than that of pure Ag foil, indicating an incomplete reduction process. At 350 °C, the catalyst exhibits a balanced coordination between Ag-O (CN = 0.6, R = 2.20 Å) and Ag-Ag (CN = 0.6, R = 2.81 Å) interactions, indicating a mixed state of partial oxidation and metallic clustering. As the temperature increases to 550°C, the Ag-O coordination decreases (CN = 0.1–0.2), while the Ag-Ag coordination also drops (CN = 0.2), suggesting a reduction in oxidation and increased dispersion or sintering of Ag particles. At 750°C, the Ag-O coordination increases again (CN = 0.4 for both Ag-O1 and Ag-O2), with shorter bond distances (R = 2.18–2.41 Å), indicating a restructuring or re-oxidation of the Ag environment. The Ag-Ag coordination further decreases (CN = 0.1), highlighting a highly dispersed state. Table 4 summarizes the IAg/IAl ratios for Ag-5/Al₂O₃-Y catalysts, showing a decreasing trend with increasing calcination temperature. This suggests reduced apparent Ag dispersion on the support. While smaller and more dispersed Ag particles were observed, the drop in this ratio may be attributed to the surface sensitivity limitations of XPS, which can underestimate signals from ultrafine or subsurface particles. The XPS spectra of Ag 3d and Al 2p supporting this analysis are provided in Fig. S.15. To investigate the thermal evolution of AgOx/Al₂O₃, in situ total scattering data was collected during calcination. PDF characterizes atomic arrangements in both ordered and disordered structures, making it suitable for complex systems. For in situ analysis, the Ag catalyst was impregnated onto the Al2O3 support and dried overnight at 80°C. The resulting dried powder was then transferred to a capillary tube and integrated into the experimental setup at the BXDS-HEW beamline of the Canadian Light Source (Fig. S.1). Experiments were performed in air and nitrogen, with the latter minimizing oxidation effects, allowing intrinsic structural changes to be distinguished from oxygen-induced transformations. Fig. 7 presents the PDF data of Ag-5/Al₂O₃-Y catalysts calcined in situ under air and nitrogen. The pattern of γ-Al2O3 at ambient temperature and simulated profiles for metallic Ag and Ag2O are also included. The γ-Al2O3 pattern aligns with reported data, showing peaks at 1.86 Å and 2.78 Å, corresponding to Al-O and Al-Al distances, respectively [18,30,31]. Notably, the overall patterns of the AgOx/Al2O3 catalysts calcined in situ under both air and nitrogen atmospheres closely resemble those of the γ-Al2O3 support. However, considering the known thermal stability of γ-Al2O3 within the applied calcination range, observed spectral changes can be attributed to alterations in the characteristics of Ag species and their interactions with the support [18]. A small peak at ∼2.3 Å appears at 350 °C and above under both air and nitrogen, as shown in Fig. 8, indicating Ag-support interactions (Al-O-Ag bonds). These interactions might be stronger under nitrogen, possibly due to the inert nature of nitrogen stabilizing surface Ag species. The higher intensity under nitrogen suggests enhanced interaction, possibly due to increased surface bonding sites available for small Ag particles. This agrees with the EXAFS results, which showed a strong Ag–O bond in the Ag-5 /Al₂O₃-350 catalyst (CN = 0.6, R = 2.20 Å), confirming the dominance of Ag¹ ⁺ species and strong Ag-support interactions. A peak at ∼2.0 Å emerges under air flow at 550 °C and above, as depicted in Fig. 8, likely due to new Ag oxide formation. This aligns with Ag2O simulations and EXAFS data, suggesting oxidation of Ag followed by decomposition. The peak broadens initially and becomes more distinct at higher temperatures, reinforcing the presence of Ag oxide species. Under nitrogen ( Fig. 9), this peak is absent, indicating the suppression of Ag oxide formation and stabilization of metallic Ag. This suggests that nitrogen prevents oxidation, maintaining the metallic Ag state throughout calcination. EXAFS further supports this trend, showing that at 550°C, Ag-O coordination decreases (CN = 0.1–0.2), suggesting partial Ag reduction. However, at 750°C, Ag-O coordination increases again (CN = 0.4), indicating possible restructuring or re-oxidation of Ag species. The Ag-Ag interaction peak (∼2.8 Å) aligns with γ-Al2O3, as observed in Fig. 8. Under air, its intensity increases from 350 °C to 550 °C but decreases at 750 °C, consistent with EXAFS results (Fig. 6 and Table 3) showing a notable Ag-Ag contribution at 550°C (CN = 0.2, R = 2.81 Å), suggesting partial reduction and metallic Ag formation. However, at 750°C, the Ag-Ag coordination further decreases (CN = 0.1), indicating increased dispersion or oxidation. This trend suggests initial particle growth followed by possible agglomeration or structural rearrangement at higher temperatures. Under nitrogen, the peak intensity decreases with temperature, suggesting smaller Ag particle sizes and differences in atomic arrangement. The decline in peak intensity under nitrogen further supports that Ag remains in a finely dispersed metallic state, preventing particle aggregation. These findings highlight how calcination atmosphere influences Ag species, their oxidation state, and interactions with the support, ultimately affecting catalyst properties and performance. To complement the main findings on Ag-5/Al₂O₃-Y, additional characterization of Ag-2.5/Al₂O₃-Y was performed to understand the impact of lower metal loading. HAADF-STEM images (Fig. S.16) revealed that no significant sintering of Ag particles occurred up to 750°C, although progressive changes in particle size and shape were observed. At 250°C, a broad size distribution was observed, from small clusters to larger agglomerates with irregular shapes, indicating active growth and mobility. By 350°C, particle sizes became more uniform and spherical, with fewer small clusters, reflecting advanced coalescence. Calcination at 550°C maintained this uniformity but reintroduced some smaller particles, possibly due to silver redistribution or Ag oxide breakdown. At 750°C, larger particles dominated, with fewer small clusters, suggesting growth and agglomeration processes prevailed. The XANES spectra of Ag-2.5/Al₂O₃-Y catalysts (Fig. S.17) showed white lines positioned between those of Ag foil and AgNO₃, with profiles resembling AgNO₃, indicating that Ag⁺ remained the dominant species. Linear combination fitting (Table S.1) revealed a gradual increase in the proportion of metallic Ag (Ag⁰) with calcination temperature, rising from 14 % at 250°C to 21 % at 750°C. The k ³ -weighted EXAFS oscillations (Fig. S.18) showed an increase in the Ag–Ag peak intensity at 750°C, in agreement with the LCF data and particle growth observed in STEM images (Fig. S.16). Interpretation of Ag–O peak intensity was more complex, as the low-distance peak at 750°C may be an artifact, while the longer-distance peak at 350°C appears more reliable. XPS spectra of Ag 3d and Al 2p (Fig. S.19) further supported these findings. The surface Ag/Al signal ratio (IAg/IAl) decreased from 0.54 at 250°C to 0.33 at 550°C, consistent with improved Ag dispersion and the transition to metallic Ag, resulting in fewer detectable surface clusters. This trend aligns with TEM and XANES data, which suggest increased Ag particle dispersion and a shift toward metallic Ag, leading to fewer detectable small Ag clusters. The XPS signal is surface-sensitive and may not detect sub-surface or covered Ag species. However, at 750°C, larger Ag particles reappear, causing IAg/IAl to rebound to 0.42. The obtained results highlighted how calcination temperature and atmosphere critically affects silver dispersion, oxidation state, and its interaction with the alumina support. Moderate temperatures enhanced metal-support interactions and partial reduction, whereas higher temperatures led to structural reorganization and surface redistribution of silver species. These findings provide a foundation for evaluating the activity in the following section. 3.2 Activity in ozonative epoxidation 3.2.1 Effect of metal loading Fig. 10 presents the performance of Ag-X/Al₂O₃-350 catalysts with varying Ag loadings in the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene at 25°C. The results show that Ag loading significantly influences catalytic activity. The 1 % Ag catalyst exhibited the lowest performance, with ethylene conversion at 62 % and ozone decomposition at 33 %, along with noticeable deactivation during the reaction. Increasing the Ag content to 5 wt% significantly enhanced both ethylene conversion (95 %) and ozone decomposition (∼100 %). However, further increasing the Ag content beyond 5 % did not improve ethylene conversion, as the 5 % and 10 % Ag catalysts showed similar activity while both fully decomposed ozone. These results indicate that higher Ag loading enhances catalytic activity, but beyond 5 %, additional Ag does not further improve ethylene conversion. Coupling these observations with the XANES and EXAFS results suggests that Ag species with lower oxidation states are more active in the catalytic ozonation of ethylene. Transition metal oxides such as Mn with lower oxidation states are reported to show higher activity in Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) ozonation, including toluene [32], acetone [12,33], and benzene [13]. Electron transfer plays a key role in ozone decomposition [34]. The high catalytic activity of Ag in ozone decomposition is attributed to its unique electronic structure, characterized by a full 4d orbital and a partially filled 5 s orbital, enabling effective electron transfer during the catalytic process. Ag is considered one of the most active metals in ozone decomposition. The presence of lattice defects on Ag surfaces, including steps, kinks, and vacancies, creates sites with distinctive electronic properties, facilitating the adsorption and activation of ozone molecules [35–37]. Ag surfaces exhibit a tendency to adsorb oxygen atoms, and these adsorbed oxygen species play a crucial role in the ozone decomposition process by assisting in the formation of reactive oxygen intermediates [38]. Under reaction conditions, the surface of Ag catalysts can undergo dynamic reconstruction, resulting in alterations to the atomic arrangement, which can significantly influence the catalytic activity [39]. These results indicate that lower AgOx oxidation states enhance electron transfer to ozone, accelerating its decomposition to atomic oxygen and increasing ethylene conversion [32]. Fig. 11 presents the reaction products from ozonative epoxidation of ethylene over Ag-X/Al₂O₃-350 catalysts. EO selectivity increases with Ag content. Catalysts with 2.5 wt% Ag and higher produced only EO and CO₂, with no CO detected. High activity of Ag in CO oxidation with ozone is attributed to highly reactive oxygen species like ozonide ions (O₃⁻) [35,40,41]. The Ag 1 % catalyst had 28 % EO selectivity, while Ag10 % reached 68 %, indicating a strong Ag-content dependency. EO selectivity trends align with XPS-derived IAg/IAl ratios (Table 2 & 4), which increase with Ag loading. A decrease in oxygen coverage arises from the consumption of surface oxygen and the formation of oxygen vacancies in ethylene epoxidation is believed to promote nonselective combustion pathway[42]. In contrast, ozonative epoxidation promotes higher oxygen coverage via ozone decomposition, inhibiting ethylene adsorption and favoring direct gas-phase reactions with surface oxygen, enhancing EO selectivity [1]. The investigation into Ag loading supports the proposed mechanism, showing that higher Ag loading improves Ag dispersion on the catalyst surface, leading to increased oxygen coverage. This enhances both EO selectivity and conversion rate. The increased Ag sites facilitate ozone decomposition, raising oxygen coverage and reducing ethylene adsorption, allowing ethylene to react more efficiently with oxygen species on the catalyst. Electrophilic oxygen species are essential for EO production, and metallic Ag is more effective in generating these species [1]. By increasing Ag content, these oxygen species become more prevalent, improving EO selectivity. Table 5 summarizes the Turn Over Frequency (TOF), reaction rate, and catalyst activity. The calculated TOF values decrease with increasing Ag loading, from 0.57 s⁻¹ at 1 wt% Ag to 0.13 s⁻¹ at 10 wt%. This trend can be attributed to the decrease in metal dispersion measured by TEM, as smaller Ag nanoparticles at low loading expose more active sites per unit mass. Thus, intrinsic per-site activity is highest at low loading. It should be noted, however, that dispersion values obtained from TEM are subject to certain limitations, such as averaging effects, assumptions on particle geometry, and sensitivity to particle size distribution. A more detailed discussion of these limitations and comparison with XPS-derived dispersion is provided in Section S.2 of the Supplementary Document. In the context of ethylene oxide production, TOF alone does not capture catalyst performance. The critical parameter is EO selectivity, which improves continuously with Ag loading, rising from 28 % at 1 wt% to 68 % at 10 wt%. As discussed earlier, this increase correlates with the steady growth of the IAg/IAl ratio obtained from XPS, which indicates higher surface coverage of Ag species at higher loadings. Greater Ag coverage provides more favorable active centers for selective ethylene epoxidation and ozone activation, which is further supported by the near-complete ozone conversion achieved at 5–10 wt% Ag. To evaluate catalyst stability under prolonged reaction conditions, Ag-X/Al₂O₃-350 catalysts (with 3.5, 5, and 10 wt% Ag) were tested over extended reaction times ( Fig. 12). Compared to earlier short-duration experiments, this set aimed to assess long-term activity and selectivity at ambient temperature. The Ag3.5 % catalyst initially showed promising performance but experienced a notable decline in ethylene conversion after approximately 200 min, accompanied by an early drop in ozone conversion. This loss in performance is likely due to the formation of surface oxide layers on small Ag clusters, which can block access to active sites and reduce catalytic activity. The accumulation of reaction intermediates may also contribute to site blockage, especially in low-loading catalysts where combustion dominates and significant water is produced—further increasing the risk of Ag site deactivation. In contrast, the Ag5 % and Ag10 % catalysts maintained stable activity and selectivity throughout the extended test period. The Ag10 % catalyst achieved 98 % ethylene conversion and 68 % selectivity to ethylene oxide, confirming its strong potential for selective EO production under mild conditions. Interestingly, a slight increase in EO selectivity was observed for the Ag3.5 % catalyst as ethylene conversion declined, echoing trends reported in conventional ethylene epoxidation systems, where lower conversion can coincide with improved selectivity [3,5]. These results emphasize the robustness of higher Ag-loaded catalysts and suggest that further performance enhancements could be achieved by introducing promoters to increase selectivity and support scalability. 3.2.2 Effect of calcination temperature Fig. 13 shows the performance of Ag-5/Al₂O₃-Y catalysts. All catalysts displayed strong activity and stability, with Ag-5/Al₂O₃-550 showing the highest activity: 99 % ethylene conversion and 100 % ozone conversion. The Ag-5/Al₂O₃-350 and Ag-5 /Al₂O₃-750 catalysts also exhibited ozone conversions over 99 %. Ethylene conversion increased from 95 % to 99 % when calcination temperature was raised from 350 to 550 °C, but slightly dropped to 96 % at 750°C. This improvement in activity could be linked to the higher metallic Ag content at 550 °C, which enhances the catalyst’s interaction with O₂/O₃ and increases the ability to generate active oxygen species. However, at 750°C, a small reduction in metallic Ag was observed, as shown by XANES, EXAFS, and in-situ PDF analyses (Fig. 5, Fig. 6, Fig. 8), which may explain the slight drop in conversion. Product distribution ( Fig. 14) revealed that all catalysts had similar EO selectivity and stability, with the Ag-5/Al₂O₃-350 catalyst having the highest EO selectivity at 56 %. Selectivity decreased slightly with increasing calcination temperature, reaching 52 % for the Ag-5/Al₂O₃-550 and 53 % for Ag-5/Al₂O₃-750 catalysts. This trend raises questions about the relationship between Ag particle dispersion and EO selectivity. Smaller Ag particles, though more active in ozone decomposition, may promote combustion reactions over epoxidation. Larger particles, which are known to be more selective for EO in traditional epoxidation, may also play a role in selectivity in ozonative epoxidation, though the extent of this influence remains unclear [3,43–45]. A slight increase in EO selectivity during the reaction was noted. This phenomenon may be linked to the participation of oxygen from Ag2O in oxygen insertion reactions, thereby accelerating EO production alongside the gas-phase generation of electrophilic oxygen species. Additionally, reduced Ag species may undergo particle size growth with larger Ag particles demonstrating enhanced selectivity toward EO [45–47]. The performance of Ag-2.5/Al₂O₃-Y catalysts in the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene was evaluated to complement the findings reported for the 5 wt% Ag catalysts (Fig. S.20 and Fig. S.21). CO₂ and EO were the main products across all samples, with CO detected only for the catalyst calcined at 250°C (Fig. S.21). Among the tested catalysts, EO selectivity increased from 35 % at 350°C to 42 % at 550°C, with no further gain observed at higher temperatures. Although higher calcination temperatures enhanced overall activity, EO selectivity remained relatively steady. This behavior suggests that the emergence of highly dispersed Ag species—likely metallic due to Ag₂O decomposition—enhances activity while introducing a more subtle effect on selectivity. This trend is consistent with the established size-dependent selectivity of silver catalysts, where larger particles typically favor EO formation, whereas smaller ones tend to promote complete oxidation to CO₂ and H₂O [32,48]. Comparative analysis between the 2.5 wt% and 5 wt% Ag catalysts, as well as evaluation of metal loading effects, indicates that increasing Ag content has a stronger influence on improving EO selectivity than calcination temperature. Higher Ag loading not only increases the fraction of metallic Ag in the catalyst but also enhances the overall Ag surface coverage, thereby promoting the selective path to EO production. Metallic Ag is considered the most selective Ag phase for EO production, mainly because of its ability to generate and stabilize electrophilic oxygen, particularly in the form of superoxide (O₂⁻), which is believed to be the most selective oxygen species for EO formation [6,42,49]. As detailed in our previous publication introducing this reaction, in the ozonative epoxidation reaction, ozone is proposed to act as a source of superoxide (O₂⁻) [1]. From the catalyst selectivity results in Fig. 11 and Fig. 14, it can be seen that EO selectivity over the bare Al₂O₃ support was even lower than that of the non-catalytic ozonation reaction, indicating that Al₂O₃ promotes a nonselective combustion pathway leading to the further conversion of EO into CO₂, and H₂O. By contrast, in Ag-containing catalysts, high surface oxygen coverage suppresses strong ethylene adsorption on nonselective sites and favors a direct, selective epoxidation pathway. This concept is illustrated in Fig. 15, which compares the catalyst surface under low and high Ag loadings. At higher Ag content, the abundance and stability of O₂⁻ species on Ag/AgOₓ sites increase, producing a more uniform and denser layer of electrophilic oxygen. This configuration minimizes ethylene adsorption on metallic Ag and promotes selective epoxidation over total oxidation, ultimately enhancing EO selectivity. 4 Conclusion This work examined how silver loading and calcination temperature affect the performance of AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalysts in the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene. Among the two factors, silver loading had a stronger impact on ethylene oxide (EO) selectivity. Increasing Ag content enhanced the abundance of metallic silver and improved its dispersion on the support surface, which facilitated ozone decomposition and increased surface oxygen coverage. This reduced the likelihood of ethylene adsorbing directly on the non-selective Al₂O₃ surface, promoting selective interaction with Ag sites and favoring EO formation. While higher calcination temperatures improved catalyst stability and ozone conversion, they did not significantly enhance EO selectivity—likely due to limited changes in surface oxygen coverage. Overall, these findings underscore the potential of ozonative epoxidation as a low-temperature, energy-efficient route for EO production. They also highlight the importance of optimizing silver loading and leveraging structural characterization tools like in situ PDF to guide the design of more selective and durable catalysts. Further research along this path could support the development of novel EO production technologies. coredata.dc:description: This work explores the ozonative epoxidation of ethylene to produce ethylene oxide over AgOx/Al₂O₃ catalysts which is a novel reaction pathway that remains underexplored due to its recent emergence. The study focuses on the effects of silver loading and calcination temperature. Higher silver loading was found to increase the abundance of silver species on the support surface, which accelerates ozone decomposition and elevates surface oxygen coverage. This enhanced oxygen coverage, along with reduced ethylene adsorption, promotes the direct formation of ethylene oxide while maintaining high conversion rates. The catalyst with 10 wt% silver achieved an ethylene conversion of 96 % and an ethylene oxide selectivity of 68 %. Increasing the calcination temperature from 350 ºC to 750 ºC altered silver oxidation states and improved catalyst stability and ozone conversion. However, no significant enhancement in ethylene oxide selectivity was observed, likely due to limited improvement in surface oxygen coverage under those conditions. which are considered beneficial for epoxidation. Structural evolution of silver species under different atmospheres was investigated using in situ pair distribution function (PDF) analysis, revealing successive redox transformations during heating. Overall, Ag loading had a more significant impact on ethylene oxide selectivity than calcination temperature, highlighting it as a key factor in optimizing catalyst performance in ozonative epoxidation.
